metadata.title: The Souvenir
metadata.subject: English
metadata.description: A science-fiction story about a school trip to the moon. Covers moon facts: gravity, settlements, sky view. Grammar: Collective nouns and punctuation review.

preAssessment.question: Who is the main character in 'The Souvenir'?
What is the moon's gravity compared to Earth's gravity?
Who was the first person to walk on the moon?
What mistake does Sayali make on the moon?
options: She buys earrings from an unauthorized seller outside the settlement
She gets lost in the moon settlement

preAssessment.question: What shape are the moon settlements described as in the story?

concepts.title: Story Setting and Plot
concepts.content: The Souvenir is a science-fiction story translated from Marathi by Lakshman Londhe. It is set in the future, when school trips to the moon are possible. The main character Sayali goes on a school trip to the moon. She is excited to see the moon settlements, experience low gravity, and see the stars. The story blends imagination with real moon science.

examples.text: School trip to the moon ‚Äî set in the future
Sayali is the protagonist ‚Äî a curious, excited student
Translated from Marathi ‚Äî originally a Marathi science-fiction story
Moon settlements exist in the story ‚Äî dome-shaped like igloos

keyPoints: The story is science-fiction ‚Äî set in the future
Translated from Marathi by Lakshman Londhe
Sayali is the main character who goes on a school moon trip
The story imagines a future where moon settlements exist
Science-fiction uses real science to imagine the future
concepts.funFact: Marathi literature has a rich tradition of science fiction! Many Marathi writers have imagined space travel and futuristic technology long before it became reality.

concepts.title: Moon Facts ‚Äî Gravity, Settlements, and Sky
concepts.content: The story includes real moon science. The moon's gravity is 1/6th of Earth's gravity ‚Äî so you feel much lighter and can jump much higher. Moon settlements are dome-shaped like igloos to withstand pressure. From the moon, the sky appears black (no atmosphere), stars are dazzlingly bright, and Earth appears 13 times bigger than the moon appears from Earth.

examples.text: Moon gravity = 1/6th Earth's gravity ‚Äî a gymnast can jump 27 metres!
Moon settlements are dome-shaped like igloos
Stars on the moon are dazzlingly bright ‚Äî no atmosphere to scatter light
Earth looks 13 times bigger from the moon than the moon looks from Earth

keyPoints: Moon's gravity is 1/6th of Earth's gravity
Lower gravity means you can jump much higher on the moon
Moon settlements are dome-shaped like igloos
The sky on the moon is always black (no atmosphere)
Stars are dazzlingly bright on the moon
Earth appears 13 times bigger from the moon than the moon from Earth
concepts.funFact: Because the moon's gravity is 1/6th of Earth's, a person weighing 60 kg on Earth would weigh only 10 kg on the moon! Indian astronaut training would be very different on the moon!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 25-26: Moon facts in the story

concepts.title: Neil Armstrong and Moon History
concepts.content: In the story, Sayali sees the preserved footprint of Neil Armstrong, the first human to walk on the moon. Neil Armstrong landed on the moon on 20 July 1969 as part of the NASA Apollo 11 mission. His famous words were: 'That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind.' Because the moon has no wind or rain, his footprint is still preserved today.

examples.text: Armstrong's footprint preserved on the moon ‚Äî no wind or rain to erase it
Apollo 11 mission ‚Äî landed on moon on 20 July 1969
'One small step for man, one giant leap for mankind' ‚Äî Armstrong's famous words
First human being to walk on another world

keyPoints: Neil Armstrong was the first human to walk on the moon
Apollo 11 mission landed on moon on 20 July 1969
His famous quote: 'One small step for man, one giant leap for mankind'
His footprint is preserved on the moon because there is no wind or rain
Sayali visits the preserved footprint on her school trip
concepts.funFact: India's own Rakesh Sharma became the first Indian to go to space in 1984! When Prime Minister Indira Gandhi asked how India looked from space, he replied 'Saare Jahan Se Accha' (the best in all the world)!

concepts.title: Sayali's Mistake ‚Äî The Heavy Earrings
concepts.content: Outside the authorized moon settlement, an unauthorized seller tries to sell souvenirs to tourists. Sayali buys earrings from this seller. On the moon, due to low gravity, the earrings feel light. But when she returns to Earth, the earrings are impossibly heavy because Earth's gravity is 6 times stronger! This is the clever twist in the story ‚Äî a lesson about buying from unauthorized sellers and understanding gravity.

examples.text: Sayali buys earrings from an unauthorized seller outside the settlement
On the moon the earrings feel light because gravity is 1/6th
On Earth the earrings are too heavy to wear ‚Äî Earth's gravity is 6x stronger
Lesson: do not buy from unauthorized sellers, and understand the science of gravity

keyPoints: Sayali buys earrings from an unauthorized seller outside the moon settlement
On the moon, the earrings feel light due to 1/6th gravity
Back on Earth, the earrings are impossibly heavy ‚Äî full Earth gravity acts on them
The story teaches that moon objects weigh much more when brought to Earth
It also teaches the lesson: do not buy from unauthorized sellers
concepts.funFact: This is why moon rocks brought back by NASA astronauts are kept in special containers! Even dust from the moon behaves differently on Earth because of the difference in gravity.
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 27-28: Sayali's earrings ‚Äî the story's twist

concepts.title: Collective Nouns ‚Äî Continued
concepts.content: Collective nouns name a group of people, animals, or things. The chapter continues the study of collective nouns from the previous chapter. Examples include: a crew of astronauts, a fleet of ships, a bunch of flowers, a pack of wolves. Each collective noun gives a specific and accurate name to a particular group, making language richer and more precise.

examples.text: A crew of astronauts boarded the spacecraft
A fleet of ships sailed across the ocean
A bunch of flowers was placed on the table
A pack of wolves roamed the forest

keyPoints: Collective noun: names a group as a single unit
Crew ‚Äî a crew of astronauts, sailors, workers
Fleet ‚Äî a fleet of ships, cars, aircraft
Bunch ‚Äî a bunch of flowers, keys, grapes
Pack ‚Äî a pack of wolves, cards, lies
Collective nouns make language more precise and interesting
concepts.funFact: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has a team of brilliant scientists. When we say 'the ISRO team', 'team' is our collective noun ‚Äî and what a proud team it is for India!

test.question: From which language was 'The Souvenir' translated?
test.explanation: The Souvenir was translated from Marathi by Lakshman Londhe. It is originally a Marathi science-fiction story.

test.question: Why can a gymnast jump 27 metres on the moon?
options: Because the moon's gravity is only 1/6th of Earth's
Because the moon has more oxygen
Because the moon's surface is very soft
Because the gymnast practises harder on the moon
test.explanation: The moon's gravity is 1/6th of Earth's, so objects and people feel much lighter and can jump much higher than on Earth.

test.question: How many times bigger does Earth appear from the moon compared to how the moon appears from Earth?
test.explanation: From the moon, Earth appears 13 times bigger than the moon appears when seen from Earth.

test.question: Why is Neil Armstrong's footprint still preserved on the moon?
options: There is no wind or rain on the moon to erase it
The moon's soil is very hard like rock
The moon is too cold to change
test.explanation: The moon has no atmosphere, so there is no wind or rain to disturb the surface. Armstrong's footprint made in 1969 is still perfectly preserved.

test.question: When did Neil Armstrong first walk on the moon?
test.explanation: Neil Armstrong first walked on the moon on 20 July 1969 as part of the NASA Apollo 11 mission.

test.question: Why were Sayali's earrings too heavy when she returned to Earth?
options: Earth's gravity is 6 times stronger than moon's gravity
The earrings were made of heavy moon rock
The earrings expanded when she came back to Earth
Sayali was tired from the journey
test.explanation: The earrings felt light on the moon because of low gravity, but on Earth with full gravity (6 times stronger), the same earrings became impossibly heavy.

test.question: What is the collective noun for a group of astronauts?
test.explanation: A crew of astronauts is the correct collective noun. 'Crew' is also used for sailors and workers.

test.question: What shape are the moon settlements described as in the story?
test.explanation: The moon settlements in the story are described as dome-shaped, like igloos, to maintain pressure and protect inhabitants.

test.question: What mistake does the story warn against?
options: Forgetting to wear a space suit
test.explanation: Sayali buys earrings from an unauthorized seller outside the moon settlement. The story teaches us not to buy from unauthorized sellers.

test.question: What is the collective noun for a group of ships?
test.explanation: A fleet of ships is the correct collective noun. Fleet is also used for a group of aircraft or cars.

keyConcepts: The Souvenir is a science-fiction story translated from Marathi by Lakshman Londhe
Sayali goes on a school trip to the moon
Moon settlements are dome-shaped like igloos
Stars are dazzlingly bright on the moon; sky is black; no atmosphere
Earth appears 13 times bigger from the moon
Neil Armstrong was first human to walk on the moon (20 July 1969, Apollo 11)
Armstrong's footprint preserved ‚Äî no wind or rain on moon
Sayali's earrings feel light on moon but too heavy on Earth ‚Äî gravity difference
Collective nouns: crew (astronauts), fleet (ships), bunch (flowers), pack (wolves)
commonMisconceptions: The moon has weather like Earth ‚Äî FALSE (no atmosphere means no wind, rain, or weather)
You would float away on the moon ‚Äî NOT EXACTLY (you feel lighter but still stay on the ground)
Armstrong's footprint would have been erased by now ‚Äî FALSE (no wind or rain to erase it)
Objects weigh the same on the moon and Earth ‚Äî FALSE (objects weigh 1/6th as much on the moon)
realWorldExamples: ISRO's Chandrayaan missions ‚Äî India's lunar exploration programme
Chandrayaan-3 successfully landed near the moon's south pole in 2023 ‚Äî India became 4th country to land on moon
Rakesh Sharma ‚Äî first Indian in space (1984, aboard Soviet Soyuz T-11)
Science fiction in Marathi literature ‚Äî examples include works by S.D. Panvalkar
Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) headquarters in Bengaluru

interactiveElement.title: Vocabulary Flashcards!
interactiveElement.description: Flip each card to reveal the meaning of the word.

cards.back: A figure of speech comparing two unlike things without using 'like' or 'as'
Repetition of the same initial consonant sound in nearby words
A word that has the same or similar meaning as another word

cards.front: What is a 'stanza' in a poem?
cards.back: A group of lines in a poem, similar to a paragraph in prose

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: From which language was 'The Souvenir' translated?
qaCards.answer: The Souvenir was translated from Marathi by Lakshman Londhe. It is originally a Marathi science-fiction story.

qaCards.answer: From the moon, Earth appears 13 times bigger than the moon appears when seen from Earth.

qaCards.answer: The moon has no atmosphere, so there is no wind or rain to disturb the surface. Armstrong's footprint made in 1969 is still perfectly preserved.

qaCards.answer: Neil Armstrong first walked on the moon on 20 July 1969 as part of the NASA Apollo 11 mission.

qaCards.answer: The earrings felt light on the moon because of low gravity, but on Earth with full gravity (6 times stronger), the same earrings became impossibly heavy.

qaCards.answer: A crew of astronauts is the correct collective noun. 'Crew' is also used for sailors and workers.

qaCards.answer: The moon settlements in the story are described as dome-shaped, like igloos, to maintain pressure and protect inhabitants.

qaCards.answer: Sayali buys earrings from an unauthorized seller outside the moon settlement. The story teaches us not to buy from unauthorized sellers.

longAnswers.question: Prepare a timetable for Sayali‚Äôs moon trip using details from the story and your imagination.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: A possible timetable is: Day 1 - shuttle journey, safe landing at Neil Armstrong base, orientation and safety briefing, night-time Sky Watch, and observation notes. Day 2 - moon circus visit, settlement tour, self-study and essay preparation. Day 3 - visit to Armstrong footprint memorial, space-suit walk in low gravity, supervised exploration and souvenir time. Return Day - departure to earth, reunion with family, and reflection on learning from the trip.
keyPoints: Timetable should follow sequence: travel, orientation, exploration, return.
Include key listed activities: Sky Watch, circus, historical visit.
Add study/reflection components as given by teacher in story.
Show time management and educational purpose of trip.

longAnswers.question: Diary writing task: Imagine you are Sayali. Write one detailed diary entry from the moon trip.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Dear Diary, Today was unforgettable. From the shuttle window, I saw earth getting smaller and the sky turning black with bright stars. At the base, we were told to follow safety rules and buy souvenirs only from authorized shops. At night, the sky looked magical and the earth looked huge and bright from the moon. I felt both excited and thoughtful. I realized space travel is not just fun; it needs discipline, observation, and responsibility. I cannot wait to write my full essay for class.
keyPoints: Diary voice should be personal and first-person.
Include feelings + observations + key events.
Reflect on learning, not just excitement.
Use story details accurately.

longAnswers.question: Discuss: Why are human settlements mentioned in the story, but not cities or villages?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The moon environment is harsh and cannot support open, naturally grown settlements like cities or villages on earth. People must live in specially engineered dome-like habitats with controlled air, pressure, temperature, and gravity conditions. These are functional scientific settlements, not socially evolved urban or rural spaces. Therefore the story correctly uses the term ‚Äúhuman settlements.‚Äù
keyPoints: Moon conditions are extreme and unfit for normal open habitation.
Habitats must be artificial and controlled.
Such living spaces are technical settlements, not conventional cities/villages.

longAnswers.question: Explain the science: Why did the earrings feel acceptable on the moon but very heavy on earth?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The moon‚Äôs gravity is about one-sixth of earth‚Äôs gravity. So an object‚Äôs weight is much less on the moon, even though its mass remains the same. Sayali judged the earrings in low gravity, where they felt lighter. On returning to earth, full gravity acted on the same earrings, making them feel much heavier and uncomfortable to wear.
keyPoints: Mass stays constant; weight depends on gravity.
Moon gravity is about 1/6 of earth gravity.
Objects feel lighter on moon, heavier on earth.

longAnswers.question: Character reflection: What mistake did Sayali make, and what lesson does the story teach?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Sayali made a hasty purchase from an unauthorized seller, ignoring clear safety instructions. She acted emotionally without checking practical suitability for earth conditions. The story teaches that excitement should be balanced with informed decision-making, especially in unfamiliar scientific environments. Following instructions and thinking before buying are essential life skills.
keyPoints: She ignored instruction to buy only from authorized shops.
Decision was impulsive and not scientifically thought through.
Lesson: responsibility, verification, and self-control in new situations.

longAnswers.question: Write in brief: What does Sayali‚Äôs moon journey reveal about future life and travel in space?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Sayali‚Äôs journey presents space travel as possible but highly regulated, educational, and technology-dependent. It suggests future life beyond earth may involve planned settlements, safety protocols, and adaptation to new physical conditions. Entertainment, tourism, and learning may all become part of space journeys. At the same time, human judgment and ethics remain as important as technology.
keyPoints: Future space travel can be normalised through technology.
Life in space requires strict systems and adaptation.
Education and awareness are central to safe exploration.
Human responsibility remains critical.
